awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: A Resilience Analytics Technology for Enhancing Seismic Rehabilitation Decision Making for Water Infrastructure Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technology to assess, analyze, and report water infrastructure resilience to disaster events. U.S. water infrastructure comprises more than 2.2 million miles of pipes, most of which are underground and unseen by millions of consumers. A large proportion of these pipes are located in areas vulnerable to earthquakes. This project targets water utilities in these critical earthquake zones (around one-fourth of all utilities in the U.S.) as potential customers. These water utilities must confront deep uncertainties about their aging water pipe networks and their ability to sustain natural and human-induced earthquakes. The utilities have to conduct a seismic vulnerability assessment and identify critical pipes in their networks that should be rehabilitated. This project may help water utilities in critical earthquake zones that need to make difficult rehabilitation decisions about their water infrastructure system. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of water infrastructure systems for a highly uncertain environment. Despite technological advances, water utility managers are often limited in their understanding of seismic concerns. The proposed resilience analytics technology provides a software application backed up with risk-based robust decision analytics algorithms to identify the best seismic rehabilitation policy with controllable risk aversion levels for a city-level network in a few minutes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The overall objective of this project was to assess the translational potential of a resilience analytics technology for enhancing seismic rehabilitation decision-making for water infrastructure systems. This technology includes a reliable, secure, and web-based software application for helping utilities make robust risk-based decisions for proactive seismic rehabilitation of water pipe networks. The team used customer and industry discovery and examined the industrial processes to assess the translational potential of the resilience analytics technology. The team completed the 2022 I-Corps Spring Cohort training and conducted 158 interviews to develop and validate a business model, including the value proposition, customer segment, channels, revenue stream, key activities, and key partners. Developing the resilience analytics technology that is based on physics-based seismic vulnerability assessment models that are fully integrated with stochastic hydraulic models is a transformative departure from existing prioritization-based algorithms for seismic rehabilitation and inspection of water pipe networks. The growing need for infrastructure maintenance creates a vibrant market for our research product.

US water infrastructure comprises more than 2.2 million miles of pipes, most of which are underground and unseen by millions of consumers. A large proportion of these pipes are located in areas vulnerable to earthquakes. This project targets water utilities in these critical earthquake zones as potential customers. These water utilities are surrounded by deep uncertainties about their aging water pipe networks and their ability to sustain natural and human-induced earthquakes. These water utilities have to conduct a seismic vulnerability assessment and identify critical pipes in their networks that should be rehabilitated. In addition, these water utilities face an enormous funding gap and highly appreciate every opportunity to get the most value out of every dollar that they spend on their infrastructure system. The resilience analytics technology will help these water utilities in the critical earthquake zones that, now more than ever before, need to make difficult rehabilitation decisions about the water infrastructure system. The project team engaged two students (including a female student) as entrepreneurial leaders through this NSF project.

 


Last Modified: 03/16/2024
Modified by: Mohsen Shahandashti
